The communal bank "Jaime Roldos" meets every 15 days in Jaramijo canton.  This is a place that is known for its beautiful beaches.  Most of the residents are very hardworking, and their work is related to the sea.

This is where Jonny, 32, lives.  His is a single father of 2 children aged 13 and 11.  Both of his children are in school.  He lives with some relatives.

Jonny is a shipbuilder.  He works for a company that builds boats.  He has to bring his own tools to work, and this is why he needs a loan to buy the tools he needs.  In time, he hopes to establish his own workshop to build boats. He also makes repairs on his own, which gives him a good income in addition to his monthly salary.

Jonny will use this loan to buy tools for his work.  He's been with his communal bank for 3 loan cycles, and he likes it because with the loan he can get ahead with his business.  His dream is to have a large workshop.

loans.use: to buy tools

loans.name: Crescencia

texts.en:
Cresencia is 29 years old and a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Cresencia has a fruit vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more fruit to sell to her customers.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Cresencia has been in this business for 11 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita works hard to support her family. Elenita is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Elenita requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Elenita has been in this business for 13 years now.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Elenita would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Dorine

texts.en:
Dorine is a hardworking married woman with one child. She lives in Bundibugyo, Uganda. Her business is cocoa farming and selling on top of operating a stall in the market, where she sales fish for supplementary income. 

She is in need of a loan to pay school fees for her child. She has a great desire of accumulating more capital and becoming a prominent cocoa dealer in her area, although she complains of the difficulties of unpredictable weather changes and limited capital.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Arzyhan

texts.ru: Арзыхан, 54 года, замужем, есть 5 детей. У Арзыхан среднее образование, она занимается полеводством и разведением скота. У нее в хозяйстве есть 4 коровы, 4 овцы. На 1,0 Га земли выращивает органический лук для реализации. На сегодняшний день деятельность Арзыхан приносит ежемесячную прибыль в сумме 13,000 сом (KGS). Для дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, она обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку семян лука и удобрений. Доходы от кредита она планирует использовать для развития своего хозяйства и постройку сарая.
texts.en:
Arzyhan is 54 years old, married, with five kids. She has completed secondary education. She cultivates plants and breeds livestock for a living. Her household comprises four cows and four sheep. On the land lot of 1.0 ha, she cultivates organic onion for sale. Right now, Arzyhan’s business provides a monthly profit of 13,000 som (KGS).
To further develop her business, Arzyhan turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) to buy onion seeds and fertilizers. She is planning to invest the borrowed money to expand her business and build a barn.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers for cultivation of organic onion

loans.name: Sompedia Pad Group

texts.fr: Malimata, membres représentatif, âgée de 56 ans est veuve et mère de 5 enfants dont un est scolarisé.Cette brave dame vend des céréales depuis 15 ans maintenant. Avec son expérience professionnel et son emplacement Malimata a une clientèle diversifiée. Elle a besoin du prêt pour acheter des céréales pour revendre. Après ses ventes, elle aura un bénéfice qui lui permettra de s'occuper de sa famille puisqu'elle est veuve et aussi de continuer son activité.
texts.en: Malimata, a representative member, is 56 years old, widowed, and the mother of 5 children, of which one is schooled. This brave woman has been selling grains for 15 years now. With this professional experience and her location, Malimata has a diverse clientele. She needs this loan in order to buy grains to resell. After her sales, she will have a profit that will allow her to take care of her family, seeing as she is a widow, and also to continue her activity.

loans.use: to buy grains (corn, small millet, beans...) to resell

loans.name: Aisalkyn

texts.ru: Айсалкын, 63 года, замужем, многодетная мама 5 детей, образование среднее. Айсалкын сейчас на пенсии, вот уже 35 лет она занимается животноводством и полеводством. В хозяйстве Айсалкын есть 2 лошади, 2 коровы, 6 овец. На 0,21 Га земли она выращивает фасоль для реализации. Ежемесячная совокупная прибыль - около 29,000 сом (KGS). В целях увеличения поголовья скота, она обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 40,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец для откорма на пастбище и последующей реализации. Айсалкын намерена и дальше увеличивать поголовье скота и отремонтировать ее дом.
texts.en:
Aisalkyn is 63 years old, married, a mother of five kids, has secondary education. Aisalkyn is retired, and for 35 years she has been breeding livestock and cultivating plants. Her household includes two horses, two cows and six sheep. On the land lot of 0.21 ha Aisalkyn cultivates beans for sale. Her monthly profit is about 29,000 som (KGS).

To increase the livestock headcount, she turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 40,000 som (KGS) to purchase sheep for fattening and further sale. Aisalkyn is planning to increase the headcount and renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy sheep for fattening and resale

loans.name: Consuelo Melva

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito Jaime Roldos se reúne cada 15 días en el cantón Jaramijo este lugar es conocido por sus hermosas playas, la mayoría de los habitantes son muy trabajadores y dedicados a las faenas del mar.
En este lugar vive la señora Consuelo, tiene 60 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen seis hijos, cinco mayores de edad y uno de 10 años de edad, los dos menores  estudian en Universidad y escuela y son los que  aun viven con ella. Su esposo se dedica a la pesca.
Doña Consuelo es una mujer muy trabajadora que le gusta a base de trabajo salir adelante,  ella  desde  hace 8 años se dedica a la venta de comida en un  pequeño comedor en su casa, allí todos los fines de semana  prepara deliciosos almuerzos y platos a la carta al gusto de sus clientes quienes en su mayoría prefieren los mariscos, ella también le da parte del crédito para que su marido lo utilice en la pesca, el tiene una pequeña embarcación en la cual realiza esta actividad y con la cual se gana la vida.
Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar arroz, carne, pescado y otros víveres para la preparación de los alimentos y carnadas y otros materiales para la pesca. Lleva 8 años en el Grupo de Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos ella puede sacar adelante su negocio. Sus sueños son que sus hijos terminen sus estudios.
texts.en:
The lending group Jaime Roldos meets every 15 days in the canton of Jaramijo, a place known for its beautiful beaches. Most of the inhabitants are very hardworking and make their living from the sea.

This is where Consuela, 60, lives. She is married and has 6 children; four of them are grown and on their own, and her 10-year-old and one child in college still live with her. Her husband is a fisherman. Consuela enjoys getting ahead as a result of working hard. For 8 years, she has sold food in a small restaurant in her house. Every weekend she prepares delicious lunches and meals a la carte to her customers' tastes. Their favorite dish is shellfish.

She is also will give part of the loan to her husband, who will use it for fishing. He has a small boat that he uses to earn his living. This loan will be used to buy rice, beef, fish and other ingredients for preparing food, as well as hooks and materials for fishing. She has 8 years with the lending group and likes it because the loans help her business to get ahead. Her dream is to have her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy rice, meat, fish and other groceries, as well as bait and fishing materials.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Sometimes, dreams are the only things you can have in life. And just like any other person, Leonila also dreams. Wanting to have her own house someday and expand her business, she is doing now her very best to excel at her craft.

Leonila is 34 years old. She is married to Ricky, a porter, and they have only one child. Currently, Leonila is busy operating her business. She sells different kinds of soft drinks and beverages. The profit she gets from the business becomes a great help for their family in terms of their daily expenses. 

To further improve the business, she wants to ask for a 9,000 PHP loan, which she will use to buy more products to sell. With this loan, she can surely gain more income and she will save part of what she gains for future investments, while part will be used for their everyday living expenses.  

You’ll be a great blessing in advance. Thanks for your heartfelt generosity and goodness. 

Leonila meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more kinds of soft drinks and beverages for resale.

loans.name: Somlawende Group

texts.en: Pauline, a representative member, is married and the mother of 3 children. 38 years old, this brave woman sells hibiscus flower juice, zoom koom (a juice made from a base of small millet), ginger juice, and water. She needs this loan to buy 2 bags of hibiscus flowers, 1 bag of small millet, 1 bag of sugar, and also the other necessary ingredients to make juice that she packs in cans and sachets to sell. After her sales, she will have a profit that will allow her to take care of the small expenditures of her family.

loans.use: to buy 2 bags of hibiscus flowers, 1 bag of small millet, and 1 bag of sugar to make juice to sell

loans.name: Syamsul

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Syamsul, one of Ruma’s agents. Syamsul lives in Tangerang, a semi urban area located about two hours' drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. He is happily married. Together with his wife, they have two cute children. 

Syamsul owns a stall that sells daily consumer products and mobile airtime credits for his community. He joined Ruma almost a year ago. He knew of Ruma from Ruma’s sales executive that came to his stall. He decided to join Ruma because he wants to expand his business in technology, as well as give more contribution to his community. 

As the business grows, Syamsul is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the loan to provide more mobile airtime credits to his community. Having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help Syamsul improve his business and accordingly, his community who needs access to such services. 

As seen in the photo, Syamsul is the one who is sitting in his own stall. He thanks you for your kind support.

loans.use: to purchase mobile airtime credits for helping his semi urban community members who need access to communication services.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children and all of them go to school. She has no additional family members. 

She sells green bananas at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the past seven years. She works six days a week. She has requested for a loan from MCDT – SACCO to buy fresh fish for resale. Her major challenges include the perishable nature of fish and transportation. Her goal and aspiration is to start selling dry fish because it takes longer to perish. 

She lives in her own house and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build a bathroom with concrete walls and necessary plumbing, since the current bathroom is lined with plastic.

loans.name: Swarnabala

texts.en:
Swarnabala is a 42-year-old rural woman. She resides in a small village in West Bengal. She is the mother of two children (one son and one daughter). Swarnabala's husband is a mason by profession. The irregular nature of his work provides no stable income, so it is very difficult to cover the household expenses for him.

Swarnabala is engaged in the cultivation of their farmland with the assistance of her son. She cultivates seasonal vegetables and crops and sells the produce at the local town market as well as to wholesalers. Though a small enterprise, it is a big effort to provide financial sustenance for the family. So it is very crucial for them to grow this agribusiness and ensure that production is abundant and of good quality. Swarnabala has an idea to cultivate paddy [rice] on their farmland. Being staple food in the region, the demand for this crop has always been good. 

Swarnabala needs financial help to purchase agricultural inputs for paddy cultivation. This is why Swarnabala is asking for a business loan from Kiva's field partner Belghoria Janakalyan Samity. The loan will be used to purchase good quality paddy seeds, fertilizers, manure, pesticides and other such resources.

Swarnabala believes that good produce will take care of her financial expenses for the rest of the year. With the savings, she plans to take on a plot of agricultural land for expanding their business. Swarnabala is thankful to her lenders.

loans.use: To buy agricultural inputs for paddy cultivation.

loans.name: Doreen Faith

texts.en:
After you taste Doreen Faith’s homemade dainties and food products, you'll crave them. Since she has the talent of making delicious food, Doreen Faith started to sell her specialties five years ago. And until now, her income from this business has aided in paying for her family’s basic necessities and expenses. 

Doreen Faith is 37 years old. She has two children with Neil, an Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW), and they live in Pasay City, Philipiines. The couple has to ensure a secure future for their children, so they are indeed striving hard to provide for the family today. 

Hoping that you can help her, Doreen Faith would like to ask for a loan amounting to 10,000 PHP. She wants to improve her small business and she would like to use this loan to purchase additional supplies of raw ingredients for her recipes. She expects that through this endeavor, she can experience a boost in her product sales. 

It is her dream to have her own place of business someday and be successful in her field. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and it is also where she can draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase additional supplies of raw ingredients for her recipes.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is 64 years old and married, with six children ranging in age from six to 27 years old. Five of the children are in school. 

He operates a retail shop, mainly selling general merchandise, salt, sugar and soap, among other items. This is supplemented by income from farming, mainly growing cassava. 

He hopes to grow and expand his business more. He will use the loan to buy more items, like salt, soap and sugar, for resale.

loans.use: to buy more items, like salt, soap and sugar, for resale.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 36 years old and married with seven children. With six children currently in school, Elena works very hard to provide for them.

Elena runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

Elena has been in this business for eight years and she sells a variety of items, such as snack food, diapers, sanitary pads, candies, biscuits, soft drinks, beer, cereals, etc. 

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

In the future, Elena would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Rwanyakabogo Kweterana Group

texts.en:
Didas is a hardworking 58-year-old married man living in Kamwenge, Uganda. For 15 years Didas has been a farmer, mainly growing coffee and pine trees. He began the business to earn a living and support his family. Didas’s dreams are growing his business and educating his children. However he is faced with a challenge of weather changes.

Didas is requesting a loan to buy pesticides for his gardens. He is a member of Rwanyakabogo Kweterana Group where group guarantorship is practiced.

loans.use: to buy pesticides for his gardens.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Corn crops are abundant in the fields of the Philippines. It is a good alternative for Filipinos when rice is unavailable. So, Nilda has chosen corn for her business. By now, she has been selling corn for years. She is 52 years of age and a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She works hand in hand with her husband, Domingo, to support and equip their household. 

Nilda buys raw corn on a wholesale basis at first. Then basically what she does every day is push her cart to where corn is being put inside large pans of hot water. There, corn is being cooked. Usually each corn costs 10 to 15 Philippine pesos (PHP). From this, she makes only an average profit, but it’s not stable since customers vary from time to time. 

Nilda is asking for a 30,000 PHP loan to buy additional raw corn for her business. This loan will be enough for her to improve her inventory and at the same time her sales. 

Nilda meets up with her co-fellowship members* weekly to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is comprised of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of raw corn for her business.

loans.name: Zaynab

texts.en:
Zaynab is a hardworking woman. She was born in the northern part of Tajikistan in 1958. She is living in a small town with her family. She is married and has four children. She is an agrarian. She plants vegetables in her yard and keeps livestock at home. She is planning to enlarge her business and gain profit from her business.

Each year she fertilizes her land to gain a good harvest. This year she does not have money to buy fertilizes and natural chemicals for her land. She appealed to IMON to get a loan to buy fertilizer and natural chemicals. She awaits KIVA lenders' kindness.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and natural chemicals

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
A warm appreciation and gratefulness flows in Norma's heart for your assistance with her previous loan worth 20,000 PHP. The loan has been utilized in purchasing more supplies of medicines and vitamin products for her drug store, which gave her additional income for the family. 

There is still a longing in Norma to further grow her business. This is why she is asking to take out a loan worth PHP 40,000 to increase her inventory of medical merchandise, such as capsules, vitamins and syrups. 

With hope and faith, she believes that one day she will see her children as successful professionals. For now, she is working very hard to make that dream come true. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional medicine products to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with seven children (three attend school). She takes care of additional family members. She lives in a rented house with access to electricity, but she does not have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees. 

Rebecca has been selling sugarcane retail at the market for ten years, working six days a week. Her challenges include high transport costs and the seasonality of sugarcane. She joined Micro Credit for Development and Transformation SACCO (MCDT SACCO) because she did not have enough capital. She has requested a loan from MCDT to buy bundles of sugarcane. Her dream is to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: to buy bundles of sugarcane.

loans.name: Divinagracia

texts.en:
It just takes a seed of faith to move mountains.

This is Divinagracia and she was able to repay the loan she got previously, worth PHP 12,000. This couldn't be possible without your help, lenders. Thank you so much! Through you, she was able to buy enough supplies of ingredients needed for her business, thus paving a way to a better remedy for her family's daily expenses.

Growing her business, she would like to ask again for a loan, worth PHP 10,000. This would be a big help for her food stall. She would use this amount to improve her food stall business by acquiring more ingredients needed in her recipes.

Help Divinagracia see a glimpse of a better future through your generosity today. With a dream to have her own restaurant and see her children become professionals in the future, she works very hard to help her husband sustain the family.

Divinagracia meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week. It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and repay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: acquire more ingredients needed in her recipes.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
It's a wonderful day, lenders!

Here is Imelda. She is 47 years old and has two children. Flinging herself into managing her current sari-sari store business, she is hopeful that in no time, she will be able to finally have more sales and build her business, as well. She is working persistently to provide for the daily needs of her household. 

A sari-sari store is seen everywhere in the Philippines, most especially along the sidewalks and streets. It is like a convenience store, but quite a bit smaller and offers only limited products which are commonly needed, such as toiletries, food, beverages and other commodities. Unlike grocery stores, sari-sari stores offer products at low-cost, which is an advantage for customers.

Making headways to improve her sales, Imelda asks for help from you. She would like to borrow a loan worth PHP 15,000 that she would use to purchase additional products and merchandise for her store. With this, she expects to grow her sales and provide a better income for her family’s daily living conditions. Today, you can be a big part of her life. 

She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God which she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase additional products and merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Edna. She is 54 years old and has four children. Flinging herself into managing her current sari-sari store business, she is hopeful that in no time, she will be able to finally get her dream house and have more business, as well. But as of now, she is working persistently to provide for the daily needs of her household. 

Sari-sari stores are seen everywhere in the Philippines, most especially along the sidewalks and streets. They are convenience stores but quite a bit smaller than the usual and offer only limited products which are commonly needed, such as toiletries, food, beverages and other commodities. Unlike grocery stores, sari-sari stores offer products at low-cost, which is an advantage for customers.

To improve her sales, Edna asks for help from you. She requests to borrow a loan worth PHP 10,000 that she would use to purchase additional products and merchandise for her store. With this, she expects to grow her sales and provide a better remedy for her family’s daily living condition. Today, you can be a big part of her life. 

She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God which she studies.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase additional products and merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice, beans, lard, soft drinks, meats, snack foods, and other items for her store.

loans.name: Albertina

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “PADRE URRACA”; la socia continua trabajando para una empresa pública y a la compra y venta de terrenos, la socia es una persona responsable, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su trabajo el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su trabajo, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el préstamo para la compra de bienes de consumo como arroz, azúcar, leche entre otros.
texts.en:
This borrower is a member of the Communal Bank “Padre Urraca”. She continues to work for a public company and also buys and sells land. She has been at her job for a long time thanks to the effort she puts forth each day into her work. She wants to keep working so that she can continue to support her family.

The borrower is requesting a loan in order to buy goods for personal consumption such as rice, sugar, milk, and other items.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk, and other items for personal consumption.

loans.name: Sasmita

texts.en:
Sasmita is a resident of Muniguda village of Rayagada district, Odisha, India. She is 32 years old. She has a small family with her husband, one son and one daughter. She and her husband are engaged with the occupation of a seasonal business at her own home village. Having an established business and permanent income, her family members still are not happy. Why? Due to the non-availability of at least a good house that they own.

It doesn’t means that they are staying at an open place, but they are staying at a rented house with a high rate of rent charged by the house owner. The rented house is made from mud and is roofed with thatch, which creates very critical situation during the rainy season. It is also very critical to stay during the winter period. The most important cause of apprehension is that the house is not completely secure and safe.

In this situation, she decided to construct at least a house roofed with asbestos for a good standard. She has already started to construct the house, but she does not have sufficient funds to complete it. So, she decided to borrow a loan from any bank or other financial institution. At this moment, Sasmita came to Mahashakti Foundation to learn about house loan details. Mahashakti Foundation decided to disburse a loan for house construction.

From the loan, Sasmita will complete the door, windows, plastering, flooring, and colouring the house. She will also complete the wiring with an electricity connection.

She is very happy to know that her house will be completed within a few months. It not only reduces the financial burden, but also helps Sasmita to feel proud to be a house owner in the society.

loans.use: to complete the door, windows, plastering, flooring, and colouring the house; also the wiring with an electricity connection.

loans.name: Rubaba United Farmers Association Group

texts.en:
Phillip is a 34-year-old hardworking man living in Kamwenge, Uganda, and the leader of this, the Rubaba United Farmers Association. He raises poultry as well as farming crops. Challenges for a poultry farmer like Phillip include high feed prices and bad weather both dry and particularly wet, when poultry is susceptible to coccidiosis, a deadly protozoan disease resulting in enteritis and bloody diarrhea.

Phillip is requesting a 5,900,000 UGX loan through Kiva's field partner HOFOKAM to be apportioned among his group, which will share liability for the loan. He will use his portion to buy more birds and feed for his farm.

Phillip’s vision is to increase the size of his poultry farm and so his income, leading to a better standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more birds and feed for his farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and manure for his banana farm.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es:
Víctor, se dedica a desarrollar labores agrícolas, inicio su negocio hace 13 años, los cultivos que realiza son de yuca y maíz, el oficio lo aprendió con la ayuda de su padre, por su experiencia hoy en día no se le dificulta administrar su negocio. Vive con su núcleo familiar.
Comprará abono, semilla, insecticidas y herbicidas para sembrar maíz y yuca, espera tener cosechas abundantes y sin problemas de plagas, así se mantendrá trabajando y tendrá mejores oportunidades de superación económica para cubrir necesidades familiares.
Sus aspiraciones son ser reconocido en la comunidad como una persona responsable y saber guiar a sus hijos para que tengan un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
Víctor farms. He started his business13 years ago. The crops he grows are corn and yuca, and he learned this occupation with the help of his father. Because of his experience, now it is not difficult for him to run his business. He lives with his family. 

He will buy fertilizer, seed, insecticides and herbicides for growing corn and yuca. He hopes to have abundant harvests, without pest problems.  In this way he will keep working and will have better opportunities for succeeding financially so that he can cover his family's  needs.  His ambition is to be recognized in the community as a responsible person, and to be able to guide his children so that they have a better future.

loans.use: Tol buy fertilizer, seed, insecticides and herbicides for growing corn and yuca.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is a 27-year-old single hardworking man. He does farming alongside his retail business selling sugar, soap, and salt. He began the business to create a side source of income to cater to the family. He hopes to expand and modernize his farm. Price fluctuation is a great challenge that affects his business.

He wishes to take a loan to plough and weed his garden.

loans.use: to plough and weed his garden.

loans.name: Yazan

texts.en:
Yazan is a brave guy. He is living in a small town with his family in Irbid and is a single guy. 

Yazan is a student at university majoring in marketing. He likes his major and wants to be a good specialist in it. Yazan applied for an educational loan to pay his higher education costs. 

He awaits Kiva lenders' support.

loans.use: To pay his higher education costs.

loans.name: Ence

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is one of Ruma’s clients, Ence. He lives in Sukabumi, a village located at the foot of Mount Gede in West Java, about 80 kilometers (50 miles) from the national capital of Indonesia, Jakarta.

Ence sells mobile phone accessories and mobile airtime credits. Even though he is still young, he is a hardworking man, and his community sees him as a cheerful and kind mobile service provider.

As his business is growing, Ence needs additional capital and is seeking a 12,000,000 IDR loan from Kiva through Ruma. He will use it to provide more mobile airtime credits for his community so people can connect with loved ones no matter how far away they are.

Ence’s goal is to serve in an e-commerce capacity for his community in relation to Ruma’s latest product called Mapan, so it can have access to better products at lower prices. He is thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to provide more mobile airtime credits for his community

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is 25 years old, married to Stephen and supports three children. She has been practicing farming for the last four years, earning KES 9,000 per month. 

Jackline has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy seedlings to plant for more farm produce to sell to gain more income. 

She plans to use the anticipated profits to educate her children to high levels. Her future hopes and plans are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy seedlings to plant for more farm produce to sell to gain more income

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is 22 years old. He is one of two siblings in Irbid. He goes to the University to get his Bachelor's degree in Finance and wants to help his family with the household expenses and his siblings with their education. Mohammad`s father died many years ago; therefore, he is applying for a loan to help him to cover the rest of the semester fees and buy the books he needs.

loans.use: to cover the rest of the semester fees and buy the books that he needs.

loans.name: Sumardi

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Sumardi, one of Ruma’s agents. Sumardi lives in Serang, located about a two hours drive from Jakarta, the capital city. He is happily married. Together with his wife, they have one cute child.

Sumardi owns a stall where he sells daily consumer products and mobile airtime credits for his community. He joined Ruma almost a year ago. He knew Ruma from Ruma’s sales executive that came to his stall. He decided to join Ruma because he wants to expand his business in technology as well as contribute more to his community.

As the business grows, Sumardi is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits to his community.

Having known about this importance, your loan will be very useful to help Sumardi improve his business and accordingly, his community who need access to such services.

Sumardi is the one who is seen in the photo. He thanks you for your kind support.

loans.use: to purchase mobile airtime credits to help his semi-urban community members who need access to communication services.

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en:
Iliya is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Gidan Maijaki Village. Iliya joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. In the past, Iliya suffered from poor yields that crippled his ability to pay for his children's school fees. 

Now that he has joined Babban Gona, Iliya has the chance to attain yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average in Nigeria, and earn an income of up to $2,000/hectare. 

Through Babban Gona’s input loan, he will have access to high-quality farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides, and improved seeds that will increase his yields and income considerably. 

With ambitious goals of harvesting 150 bags of maize this year, Iliya can now ensure that his children get a post-secondary school education.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Felipe De La Cruz

texts.es: Felipe de 35 años de edad se dedica desde hace 6 años a la agricultura siembra maíz y frijoles, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su casa, también se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pan, vive con su esposa y sus cuatro hijos en casa propia, el está solicitando un crédito para la compra de fertilizantes para asistir sus cultivos y continuar con su trabajo para tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
35 year old Felipe has made his living for the last 6 years in agriculture, planting corn and beans and marketing his products in the different markets that are found near his house. He also makes and sells bread.

He lives with his wife and their four children in their own house. He is asking for a loan to purchase fertilizers to help his crops and to continue with his work in order to improve income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers to help his crops.

loans.name: Nura

texts.en: Nura is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Danju Village. Nura joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Nura will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilisers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Nura now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his additional earnings to build a better home for his family.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: La joven a quien se le ha pixeleado la cara por tener 28 años de edad y vivir en zona de alto riesgo, se dedica a la agricultura cultiva maíz y frijol desde hace 5 años inicio con capital propio, cuando ya está su cosecha la comercializa en los pueblos aledaños, ya tiene muchos clientes fijos, la joven vive en casa propia con su esposo, ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, herbicidas, etc. y mejorar el terreno que muestra en la fotografía para poder continuar con sus cultivos ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo y así tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
The young woman whose face is pixelated since she is 28 years old and lives in a high risk zone, makes a living in agriculture. She has grown corn and beans for 5 years. She started with her own capital, and when her harvest is ready, she sells it in the neighboring towns. She now has a lot of loyal clients. The young woman lives in her own house with her husband.

She is asking for the loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides, etc. and improve the land shown in the photograph to be able to continue with her farming, since that is her only source of work and that way she can have a better income.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides, etc., to improve the land

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seedlings to plant for more farm produce to sell and gain more income

loans.name: Elma Lou

texts.en:
Elma Lou works hard to support her family. Elma Lou is married and has an Internet cafe business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF to pay for electric and Internet bills and purchase an additional computer for her business.

Elma Lou has been in a business for 20 years now. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Elma Lou would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to pay for electric and Internet bills and purchase an additional computer for her business

loans.name: Trapoh Group

texts.en:
The Trapoh Group is led by a 31-year-old young farmer Mono, who is standing in the second row and pointing his right hand up in the photo. The other farmers in the group are Anto, Subhan, Ari, Madi, Ito, Gatot, Mui, Sam and Khoirul. They are posing on an unfinished bio-digester. Mono has a family with one child. All of them live in a small village in Rembang, the northern coast region of Central Java, Indonesia.

In his daily life, Mono works as a teacher at a local Elementary School. He also has been running a small-scale vegetable farm. Six months ago, he invited nine of his colleagues to start a cow-fattening business. His business is going quite well. Mono was concerned to see that many young people in his village would have preferred to become construction workers in the nearby cities, compared to continuing their education or rather than advancing agriculture businesses in their village. However, he is deeply concerned to see a high price and scarcity of non-renewable cooking gas, and the cow dung that is wasted without further processing, which is polluting the water in his village.

After socializing with Yayasan Rumah Energi (YRE) and At-Tayseer Foundation (a local educational foundation – biogas construction partner of YRE) about the Household Biogas (BIRU) program, Mono saw that biogas is a good solution of his problem. He saw an opportunity to reduce his dependence on non-renewable cooking gas. In addition, he also wants to use bio-slurry (biogas residue) as organic fertilizer for his plants. He is so keen to purchase a bio-digester, but he does not have sufficient capital for it. A loan from Kiva will help Mono and other farmer group members to make it possible.

He has an optimism that if he can build a bio-digester, he can use the bio-gas for cooking, and bio-slurry (biogas residue) as fertilizer for his plantation. He hopes that in the future, he can invite all the farmers in his village to use biogas, create new jobs for local people, reduce the rate of urbanization and help his village to become energy and food self-sufficient.

loans.use: To build a bio-digester facility and use the biogas residue as organic fertilizer

loans.name: Apep

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Apep, one of Ruma's agents. Apep lives in Sukabumi, a city located at the foot of Mount Gede in West Java, about 80 km (50 miles) from the national capital of Indonesia, Jakarta. He lives there with his wife. Apep owns a stall that sells stationary and mobile airtime credits. Apep joined Ruma last year, and he decided to join Ruma because he wants to expand his business in technology, as well as give more contribution to his community.

As the business grows, Apep needs additional capital and is seeking a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits for his community, so his community can connect with their loved ones no matter how far they are apart. Apep’s goal towards Ruma in the near future is to serve as an e-commerce business for his community with Ruma’s latest product called Mapan, so later, his community can have access to better products with lower prices. 

Apep is the one who is seen in the photo. He is thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to purchase mobile airtime credits for helping his village community members who need access to communication services.

loans.name: Laázarus

texts.en: Laázarus is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Bazana II Village. Laázarus joined Babban Gona to increase his wealth. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Laázarus will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags of maize.  This season, Laázarus has grand plans to harvest 50 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Laázarus now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his extra earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Auwalu Muhammadu

texts.en:
Auwalu Muhammadu is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Danju Village. Auwalu Muhammadu joined Babban Gona to expand his farm and grow his agricultural business. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Auwalu Muhammadu will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him  earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. 

Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Auwalu Muhammadu now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his extra earnings to purchase a motorbike for his business.

loans.use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yields

loans.name: Tisongmi Taba - Nyong Nayili Group

texts.en:
Kubura is 40 years old and married with five children. She is a member of a shea nut processing group called Tisongmi Taba, Nyong-Nayili in the northern region of Ghana. 

Kubura is the individual sitting in the middle in front with her hand raised. 

Her group has been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to process premium shea nuts and butter for the local and export markets. Kubura earns good profit from her business and has requested a loan of GHS 10,800 together with her group. Her own share of the loan is GHS 400, which she will use to buy processing equipment. 

Kubura wants to earn more income to repay the loan and support her family. Kubura is grateful to Kiva lenders for changing her life.

loans.use: to buy processing equipment for shea nuts

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a married woman with three children. She is a business lady dealing in ladies' garments. She resides in Kiwatule-Wakiso. She does her business from Ntinda. She generates some profits from her business and uses them to take care of the children's school fees and other household needs.  

Evelyn is a third-time borrower. She wants to expand her business by increasing her stock and also start buying and selling men's garments to supplement.

She has opted to borrow UGX 2,000,000 to boost her business. Her target is to have a full boutique a year from now.

She appreciates UGAFODE's financial boost and support.

loans.use: to buy garments for sale

loans.name: Victorine

texts.en:
She is married with five children. They all live in a four-bedroom house in Bamenda, in the northwest region of Cameroon. She has faced so many difficulties in life, including sickness of her family, death of her loved ones and inadequate finances to start a business of her own to cater to her family's needs and pay for her children’s school fees, 

With this new loan she requested, she will buy fowl, feeders, medicine, feed, manure, fertilizer, insecticides and seedlings. She holds a positive view of this business succeeding because she has been in the agricultural field for a long time. With this business activity, the community will benefit from her activity in that she will provide food for the population and manure for gardeners in the local community.

With the profit made from this loan, she will expand her farm, pay her children's school fees and save some in order to undertake a bigger investment; she will provide medication for her family and will also build her house. She prefers a GHAPE loan because of low interest rates, convenient repayment intervals and the training that the members receive in marketing and management skills before the loans are disbursed.

loans.use: To buy fowl, feeders, medicine, seedlings, manure, fertilizer, and insecticides.

loans.name: Emel

texts.en:
Emel is married and has one child. After retiring, she moved to a different city. There, she thought of doing various things in order to find friends and pass her time. She met women selling their products by the sea.  After learning the procedure, she rented a stand and started making and selling jewelry. She did this for more than seven years but then this year, she had a trouble with her knee and could not open a stand. But her customers would not leave her, so she continued working from home. With the help of the loan, she is planning to buy silver jewelry.

Translated from Turkish by Maya staff
Emel  Hanım evli, bir çocuk annesi.  Emekli olduktan sonra geldikleri şehirde çevre edinebilmek ve zaman geçirmek için bir şeyler yapmayı düşünürken sahilde satış yapan kadınlarla tanışır.  Prosedürü öğrendik den sonra kendisi de sahilde tezgah kiralayarak hazır takılar yapıp satmaya başlamış.  Yedi yıldan fazladır bu işi yapan Emel hanım bu sene dizinden geçirdiği bir rahatsızlıktan dolayı tezgah açamadı,  ama müşterileri onu bırakmadığından satışlarına evden devam ediyor. Siparişlerini de bizzat müşterilerini ziyaret ederek satıyor. Aldığı kredi ile gümüş takılar alacak.

loans.use: to buy silver jewelry

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a Babban Gona farmer from Bazana II Village. Ibrahim joined Babban Gona to become a better farmer. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Ibrahim will have access to top-of-the-range farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides, and improved seeds. This loan will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare, double the 14 bags per hectare earned by the average Nigerian smallholder maize farmer. With the opportunity to earn high yields and increase his net income, Ibrahim would like to use his extra earnings to ensure all his children get a post-secondary education.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 61 years old and married with grown-up children who are taking care of themselves. She works hard to provide for herself. She runs a business selling wax print clothing and frozen food in Chorkor, Accra. She has been selling wax print clothing and frozen food for 14 years. Mary has requested a loan of 2,700 GHS through ID Ghana to buy more wax print clothing and frozen food to sell. She has borrowed and repaid 10 loans from ID Ghana before this loan. She aspires to save enough money so she can afford to take care of herself.

loans.use: To buy more wax print clothing and frozen food to sell.

loans.name: Chairul

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Chairul, one of Ruma's agents. Chairul lives in Sukabumi, a village located at the foot of Mount Gede in West Java, about 80 km (50 miles) from the national capital of Indonesia, Jakarta. Chairul is a young guy who owns a stall that sells stationary and mobile airtime credits. Chairul joined Ruma last year and he decided to join Ruma because he wanted to expand his business with technology. He is a hardworking man and his community sees him as a cheerful and kind mobile service provider.

As the business grows, Chairul needs additional capital and is seeking a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits for his community, so his community can connect with their loved ones no matter how far they are apart. Chairul’s goal towards Ruma in the near future is to serve as an e-commerce business for his community, Ruma’s latest product called Mapan, so later, his community can have access to better products with lower prices. Chairul is the one who is seen in the photo. He is thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to purchase mobile airtime credits to help his village community members who need access to communication services.

loans.name: Irmiya

texts.en: Irmiya is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Gidan Maijaki Village. Irmiya joined Babban Gona to expand his farm and grow his agricultural business. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Irmiya will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilisers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Irmiya now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his extra earnings to buy maize grinding machines.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya is a Babban Gona farmer from Gogarma Village. Iliya joined Babban Gona to become a better farmer. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Iliya will have access to top-of-the-range farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides, and improved seeds. This loan will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare, double the 14 bags per hectare earned by the average Nigerian smallholder maize farmer. With the opportunity to earn high yields and increase his net income, Iliya would like to use his extra earnings to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Slamet

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Slamet, one of Ruma's agents. Slamet lives in Semarang, a city located in Central Java, around two hours by plane from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. He lives there with his wife and his two sons. He owns a stall that sells mobile airtime credits to his community. He decided to join Ruma because he heard that Ruma has the best service and system. His community sees him as an informative and trusted mobile provider. 

As the business grows, Slamet needs additional capital and is seeking a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits to his community. Slamet’s goal towards Ruma in the near future is to serve as an e-commerce business for his community with Ruma’s latest product called Mapan so that later, his community can have access to better products with lower prices. Slamet is the one who is seen in the photo. He is thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to process more prepaid mobile airtime purchases and electricity bill payments for members of his local community.

loans.name: Hülya Şenel

texts.en:
Hülya is divorced and has a daughter. In order to overcome her financial difficulties, she made jewelry and sold it to her neighbors from home. Then, she bought a stand and sold the jewelry by the sea. She has been making jewelry for 10 years and she has been selling it in an art gallery for two years. This year, she wants to make a change and add new products such as candles, soaps and some ornaments. With the help of the loan, she is planning to purchase materials in bulk.

Translated from Turkish by Maya staff
Hülya Hanım eşinden boşanmış bir kız annesi. Geçim sıkıntısını aşmak için evde yapıp çevresine sattığı takıları sahilde tezgah alarak satmaya devam etmiş. On bir yıldır takı yapıp satıyor. İki yıldır da sanat galerisinde tezgah açıp satış yapıyor. Bu yıl değişiklik yapmak istediğinden takılarının yanın da mum sabunlar ve değişik hediyelik eşya satışı yapmak istiyor. Aldığı kredi ile de toplu malzeme alacak.

loans.use: to buy materials to make candles, soaps and some ornaments

loans.name: Melahat

texts.en:
Melahat is married and is a mother or four. 

For years she worked in various jobs to earn her family's living all by herself. When the art gallery was opened, she applied to the municipality and got herself a stand. She sells the knitted products she makes (scarves, bathing fabrics, sweaters), as well as the covers and overlays she makes with tulle and lace. 

With the help of the loan, she is planning to purchase bulks of tulles and laces to make sets of napkins, tea services, bedsheets and covers to sell.

Translated from Turkish by Maya staff
Melahat Hanım evli , dört çocuk annesi. Yıllarca çeşitli işlerde çalışarak ailesinin geçimini tek başına üstlenmiş. Sanat galerisi açılınca belediyeye müracaat ederek burada tezgah almış. Tezgahında yaptığı el işlerinin(örme lif,şal,hırka)yanında tül ve güpürden diktiği örtülerin satışını da yapıyor. Aldığı kredi ile toplu tül ve güpür alacak. Bunlarla oda takımları dikip satış yapacak.

loans.use: to buy bulks of tulles and laces

loans.name: Umar

texts.en:
Umar is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Dangashi Village. He joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. 

In the past, Umar suffered from poor yields that crippled his ability to purchase better inputs to improve his yields. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Umar will have access to the best farm inputs on the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare, which is double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will help him increase his household income considerably.

Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Umar now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income, and to use his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Munisahon

texts.en:
Munisahon is a hardworking woman. She was born in the northern part of Tajikistan in 1967. She is married and has two children, and she lives in a small town with her family. Her family is big and they live happily with each other.  

Munisahon works at a collective farm and she has her own land where she plants vegetables and cereals. Each season, she tries to look after her land and she takes care of her plantings. 

This season, she wants to plant more vegetables and cereals in order to earn profit from her harvest. She has therefore asked for a loan from Kiva and IMON to buy fertilizer and natural chemicals. 

She awaits Kiva lenders' compassion.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and natural chemicals

loans.name: Kabiru Tall Man

texts.en:
Kabiru Tall Man is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Hamidu Village. He joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children.

In the past, Kabiru Tall Man suffered from poor yields that crippled his ability to purchase better inputs to improve his yield. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Kabiru Tall Man will have access to the best farm inputs on the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize per hectare, which is double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will help him increase his household income considerably. 

Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Kabiru Tall Man now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income, and use his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase his yields

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is married and is a mother of two.  

She and her husband run a small "döner" shop. With advice from her friends, she took out her first loan and bought materials for her shop. 

With the help of this second loan, she is planning to expand their business.
 


Translated from Turkish by Maya staff:

Fatma hanım evli iki çocuk annesi eşi ile beraber dönerci dükkanı işletiyor.  Mikro krediyi bir arkadaşından duymuş  ve kredi kullandı.  Dönerci dükkanına malzeme alarak işini geliştirmek istiyor.

loans.use: to buy meat and other materials for her 'döner' shop

loans.name: Upendo Onds Group

texts.fr: L'activité rizicole a intéressé Jeannot depuis son bas âge car elle était pratiquée par la grande partie de paysans vu sa rentabilité par rapport aux autres cultures. Les capitaux insuffisants, les maladies de plantes ainsi que la destruction des prédateurs constituent ses obstacles; cela ne limite pas pour autant ses ambitions quant à l'accroissement de revenus afin de supporter efficacement les études de ses enfants et d'améliorer son habitat. Président du groupe UPENDO ONDS, Jeannot tient dans sa main un carnet rose.
texts.en:
Jeannot has been interested in growing rice since he was very young.  Rice growing is carried out by many farmers as it is more profitable than other crops.

Lack of working capital, plant diseases and the elimination of pests are all things that preoccupy Jeannot, but he remains optimistic about increasing his income and supporting his children in their education and improving their living conditions.

Jeannot is the president of the 'Upendo Onds' Group and is seen in the photo with a pink booklet in his hand.

loans.use: to buy phytosanitary products and fertilizer, and pay for labour for his agriculture business.

loans.name: Sabari Kadi Group

texts.fr:
Mme MARCELINE est responsable du groupe  SABARI KADI. Mariée, Elle est mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 09 ans et le moins âgé a 04 ans et 06 mois. 01 enfant va à l’école et elle a 02 personnes en charge.
Madame fait le commerce d’habits  depuis 04 ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans  les  marchés  environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, elle compte s’acheter 05 douzaines d’habits, 04 pièces de pagnes et 06 douzaines d’habits pour enfants.
Elle veut épargner ses bénéfices. Elle ambitionne ouvrir une grande boutique de prêts à porter et voudrait aussi améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Marceline is the representative of the 'Sabari Kadi' Group.  She is married and mother to two children aged nine years and four-and-a-half years old.  One of her children currently attends school and she is responsible for two people.

Marceline has been selling clothing for four years.  She buys her supplies in local markets and will use her loan to buy five dozen items of clothing, four pagnes (traditional, wrap-around clothing) and six dozen items of clothing for children.  She plans to save her profits and one day open a large shop selling ready-to-wear clothing.  She would also like to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy 5 dozen items of clothing, 4 pagnes (traditional, wrap-around clothing) and 6 dozen items of clothing for children.

loans.name: Murah Rejeki Group

texts.en:
The Murah Rejeki Group members are standing in front of a cow house. This farmer group is led by the 41-year-old farmer Tulus, who is standing on the far right and pointing his thumb up in the photo. The other farmers in the group are Gimin, Senen, Tri, Ati and Adi. Tulus has a family with three children. All of them live in a small village in Sleman, Jogjakarta, Indonesia.

Tulus strives to improve his family's economic conditions. He has been doing small-scale vegetable farming and has a few cows to be fattened for resale. His business is going quite well. However, he was deeply concerned to see the high price and scarcity of non-renewable cooking gas, and also was seeing the cow dung was wasted without further processing, which pollutes the air with a pungent odor.

After introduction by Yayasan Rumah Energi (YRE) and Bina Energy Mandiri Persada, CV (a local business enterprise/biogas construction partner of YRE) to the Household Biogas (BIRU) program, Tulus saw that biogas is a good solution for his problem. He saw the opportunity to reduce his dependence on non-renewable cooking gas. In addition, he also wants to use bio-slurry (biogas residue) as organic fertilizer for his plants. In order to make it happen, Tulus invited three of his friends above to form a farmer group. He is keen to purchase a bio-digester, but he does not have sufficient capital for it. A loan from Kiva will help him and the other farmer group members to make it possible.

Tulus has optimism that if he can build a bio-digester, he can use the bio-gas for cooking, and bio-slurry (biogas residue) as fertilizer on his plantation. He also want to sell the remaining bio-slurry to increase his family income. He hopes that in the future, he can invite all the farmers in his village to use biogas and help his village to become an energy and food self-sufficient village.

loans.use: to build a bio-digester facility and utilize the biogas residue as organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Cira's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de  30 membres fait partie du banc villageois qui a été crée le 16 novembre 2010. Il est constitué de femmes du même quartier qui s'activent dans le commerce et qui ont de bonnes relations.
SOKNA à droite de la photo est âgée de 50 ans, mariée et mère 7 enfants dont 3 garçons et 4 filles.
Avec le prêt reçu, elle va acheter de l'arachide et des parfums. Pour l'arachide, elle se rend au marché de diourbel pour acheter 2 barils à 20 000 FCFA l'un pour le revendre à 25 000 FCFA. Pour les parfums, elle se rend à touba pour en acheter 20 à 500 FCFA l'un et revend l'unité à 700 FCFA.
Les bénéfices générées vont lui permettre d'assurer sa part dans les tontines dont elle fait partie et aussi répondre aux  charges familiales.
texts.en:
This group of thirty members are part of the 'Banc Villageois' which was created on 16th November 2010.  It is made up of women who all live in the same neighbourhood, work in retail and have a very good working relationship.

Sokna (seen on the right in the photo) is fifty years old, married and mother to seven children (three boys and four girls).  Her loan will buy peanuts and perfume.  She will buy two barrels of peanuts at the Diourbel market for 20,000 francs CFA each.  She will then sell them for 25,000 francs CFA each.  The perfume comes from Touba and she will buy twenty for 500 francs CFA each and resell them for 700 francs CFA each.

Sokna will use her profits to pay her part of the tontines (savings groups) of which she is a member, and also contribute to her family's expenses.

loans.use: to buy peanuts and perfume for resale.

loans.name: Deni

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Deni, one of Ruma's agents. He is the head of one village in Cianjur, West Java, around 2 hours and 30 minutes from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. He lives there with his wife and his children (one son and two daughters). As the head of the village, Deni realized that his community really needed access to a better communication service and that's why he decided to join Ruma. His community sees him as a man with strong leadership as well as an excellent mobile provider.

As the business grows, Deni needs additional capital and is seeking a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits to his community. Deni’s goal towards Ruma in the near future is to serve as an e-commerce business for his community with Ruma’s latest product called Mapan, so later, his community not only can have access to communication service, but also access to buy high quality products with lower prices. Deni is the one who is seen in the photo. He is thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to give his village community better access to communication service by selling mobile airtime credits.

loans.name: Wada

texts.en: Wada  is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Dangashi Village. He joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. In the past, Wada suffered from poor yields that crippled his ability to purchase better inputs to improve his yields. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Wada will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Wada now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yields.

loans.name: Çiğdem

texts.en:
Çiğdem took over a cafe four years ago and she is running it with the help of her family. She works more intensively in summers and this summer she is planning to serve breakfast and also lunch on weekends. With the help of her fourth loan and with her savings she will prepare her cafe for the summer. With this loan she will buy materials for her cafe. She wants her cafe to be popular and expand her business.

Translated from Turkish by Maya staff
Çiğdem Hanım dört buçuk yıl önce devraldığı çay bahçesini ailesinin desteği ile işletiyor. Yaz aylarında daha yoğun çalışan Çiğdem Hanım bu sezon değişiklik yaparak sabah kahvaltı, hafta sonu yemek verecek. Maya dan aldığı dördüncü krediye kendi birikimini de katarak yaz sezonuna hazırlıklarını tamamlayacak . Çay bahçesinin aranan bir işletme haline gelmesi için çalışıyor ve daha da büyümek istiyor.

loans.use: to buy materials

loans.name: Hamisu

texts.en: Hamisu is a Babban Gona maize farmer from  Dangashi Village. He joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. In the past, Hamisu suffered from poor yields that crippled his ability to purchase better inputs to improve his yield. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Hamisu will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Hamisu now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yields.

loans.name: Mbene

texts.fr:
Ce membre fait partie du banc villageois qui a été crée le 16 novembre 2010.Il est constitué de femmes du même quartier qui s'activent dans le commerce et qui ont de bonnes relations.
MBENE sur la photo est âgée de 63 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont 2 filles et 2 garçons.
Avec le prêt reçu, elle se rend au marché de diourbel pour acheter du café. Elle achète 15 sacs de café l'unité à 20 000 FCFA et revend le sac à 22 000 FCFA. C'est une activité qu'elle mène cinq fois pendant six mois. 
Les bénéfices lui serviront à épargner, répondre aux charges familiales et enfin réinvestir dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mbene is a member of the 'Banc Villageois' which was created on 16th November 2010.  The Banc Villageois is made up of women who live in the same district, work in retail and have a good working relationship.

Mbene is sixty-three years old, married and mother to four children (two girls and two boys).  Her loan will buy fifteen sacks of coffee from the market in Diourbel.  She pays 20,000 francs CFA a sack and sells it for 22,000 francs CFA a sack.  She does this five times in every six month period.  Her profits will be used to increase her savings, provide for the expenses of the family and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy coffee to sell.

loans.name: Idi

texts.en: Idi is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Dangashi Village. He joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. In the past, Idi suffered from poor yields that crippled his ability to purchase better inputs to improve his yield. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Idi will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Idi now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yields.

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en: Emmy operates a business selling spare parts in the town of Masindi, Uganda. He is married with one child who goes to school. He started the business to cater for his family needs and have a source of income to get school fees for his child as a loving father. His greatest desire is ensuring that his child gets educated in the best schools. Despite his plans, Emmy has difficulty with inadequate capital to buy enough stock to sell. He is requesting a loan to buy spare parts to sell.

loans.use: to buy spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Colobane Fass Group

texts.fr: Le banc villageois de Colobane Fass a été inauguré le 19 Février 2001. Le groupe est composé de sept femmes qui s'activent dans le commerce particulièrement la vente des produits halieutiques. Elle se soutiennent solidairement et remboursent leurs prêts sans difficultés. Madame Fatou qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est la représentant du groupe. Elle est mariée, âgée de 49 ans et mère de sept enfants dont cinq filles et deux garçons. Elle s'active dans la vente de produits halieutiques depuis plusieurs années. Elle va acheter avec le crédit sollicité 300 kg de crevettes. Elle n'est pas la seule à mener cette activité dans sa localité mais elle a des clients qui lui sont fidèles. Les bénéfices vont servir à la prise en charge de sa famille
texts.en:
The Colobane Fass 'Banc Villageois' was founded on 19th February 2001.  There are seven members in the group and they all work in retail, particularly retailing fish products.  They provide a lot of support for one another and their loans are always repaid with no problems.

Fatou, on the right in the photo with her hand raised, is the group representative.  She is forty-nine years old, married and has seven children (five girls and two boys).  She has been selling fish products for many years and her loan will buy 300 kilos of prawns.  She isn't the only one to be selling prawns in her area but she has many loyal customers.  Her profits will provide for her family.

loans.use: to buy fish products for sale.

loans.name: Walter

texts.en: Walter is a married man. He has one child. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for two years. His primary customers are regular. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. He will use the KES 35,000 loan to service and maintain his motorcycle. His business goal is to be a transport manager within five years.

loans.use: to service and maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard sells textile clothes which generate income for his family. He is a hardworking married man with five children living in Masindi, Uganda. He built houses for rent so as to generate more income. To supplement his incomes he sells clothes, having engaged in business to cater for the family needs. His problem is high rental costs which reduce his projected profits. Richard is requesting a loan to buy textile clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy textile clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilisers, manure, anti-disease treatments, weed-killers and more.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos se dedica desde hace varios años a la agricultura siembra maíz y frijol, comercializa sus productos en los diferentes mercados que se encuentran cerca de su casa, vive con su esposa y su hija en casa propia, el está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, etc. y mejorar el terreno que muestra en la fotografía para poder continuar con su trabajo y tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
For a number of years, Carlos has made a living in farming. He grows corn and beans, and sells his products in the different markets near to his home. Carlos lives with his wife and daughter in a house that the family owns.

Carlos is applying for a loan in order to buy seeds, fertilisers, manure, anti-disease treatments and more to improve his land (shown in the photo) and to be able to continue with his work and earn a higher income.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilisers, manure, anti-disease treatments and more to improve his land.

loans.name: Esperanza Y Amor Group

texts.es: “ESPERANZA Y AMOR” es un grupo conformado por socios dedicados al comercio minorista. Carlos tiene 32 años de edad es soltero dedicado a la venta de miel de abeja café tostado hace dos años. Años atrás trabajaba como agricultor. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de más miel de abeja y café tostado. El grupo agradece a los inversionistas KIVA por el crédito brindado. Carlos es la segunda persona sentada del lado derecho.
texts.en:
The “Esperanza y Amor” group’s members are all retailers.

One member, Carlos, is 32 years old and single. He has been making a living selling coffee and honey for two years. Previously he worked as a farmer. Carlos will use this loan to buy more honey and coffee.

The “Esperanza y Amor” group is grateful to Kiva investors for this loan.

In the photo, Carlos is sitting down, the second on the right.

loans.use: to buy more honey and coffee.

loans.name: Coumba Croi.'s Group

texts.fr:
Créé le 22 Janvier 2003, ce banc villageois est composé de femmes qui habitent le même le village .Elles ont comme activité le petit commerce et sont très solidaires entre elles.

Madame Coumba, âgée de 42 ans (assise à l’extrême  droite avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 filles et 02 garçons. Elle est commerçante de sucre, de café , de lait et de thé.

Avec son nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter du sucre d’une valeur de 100 000f, 05 bidons d’huile raffinée de 20 litres à 17000f l’un du lait d’un montant de 40000 et d’autres condiments pour le revendre en détails.

Avec les bénéfices, elle compte s’occuper de ses enfants (scolarités, habillements) et renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
The 'Banc Villageois' was created on 22nd January 2003 and is made up of women who all live in the same village.  They all work in retail and are mutually very supportive.

Coumba (sitting on the far right in the photo with her hand raised) is forty-two years old and represents the group.  She is married and has two daughters and two sons.  She sells sugar, coffee, milk and tea.  Her loan will buy 100,000 francs CFA of sugar, five 20 litre drums of refined oil for 17,000 francs CFA each, milk for 40,000 francs CFA and other food items for retail.

Coumba will use her profits to provide for her children (education and clothing) and increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy sugar, refined oil, milk and other food items for resale.

loans.name: Leslie Auxiliadora

texts.es:
